title: Lamblin & Fils 2018 Les Clos Grand Cru  (Chablis)
description: Initial, yeasty funk clouds bright lemon, chalk and Mirabelle notes on the nose of this wine. The palate then moves that buffered, textured chalkiness center stage. It offers generosity and beautiful concentration, with a roundness that speaks of lemon, stone, freshness and ripeness. This wine is expressive, elegant and very long.

title: Liminal 2018 Block Highlight Series Block 16 WeatherEye Vineyard Syrah (Columbia Valley (WA))
description: Fruit for this wine comes from the highest block currently planted on Red Mountain, north facing at the top of the ridge, outside the AVA boundaries. Aged in 25% new French oak, it's the most brooding of the winery's inaugural releases, with notes of dried herb, blackberry, coffee and clove. It's dazzling in its intensity and layering, saturating the palate from end to end while still showing fleetness of foot. Packed full of tannin and acid, it absolutely sails on the finish. The balance is exquisite. Best after 2025.
designation: Block Highlight Series Block 16 WeatherEye Vineyard

title: Domaine Christian Moreau Père et Fils 2018 Valmur Grand Cru  (Chablis)
description: The appetizing nose on this wine offers creamy, nutty and lemon-scented freshness. The palate adds supersmooth, juicy ripeness that suggests yellow apple, juicy Mirabelle and a touch of honey from the ripeness of 2018. There is wonderful freshness, however, and cool, chalky depth that turns this into a balanced, rounded, mouthwatering wine with real dimension. The finish is zesty and long. Drink 2022–2040.
winery: Domaine Christian Moreau Père et Fils

title: Domaine Christophe Pichon 2017 La Comtesse en Côte Blonde  (Côte Rôtie)
description: Packed with pristine black cherry and raspberry flavor, this medium-bodied Syrah is a gloriously perfumed expression of Côte Blonde. It's sunny and charming in fruit profile but elevated by subtle hints of fur, crushed earth and charred bramble, too. While tempting in its youth, it should gain complexity well past 2030.

title: M. Chapoutier 2016 De l'Orée White (Hermitage)
description: Wisps of tea leaves and caramelized honey swirl into freshly pressed apple and pear in this complex, elegant Marsanne. While intensely ripe and unctuous in mouthfeel, it's a remarkably pure sip brightened by soft tangerine acidity and a bristling mineral finish. Although enticing young, it should develop more earthen, honeyed complexities over the next decades.

title: Mascarello Giuseppe e Figlio 2015 Perno Vigna Santo Stefano  (Barolo)
description: Enticing aromas of red berry, baking spice, crushed rose and chopped mint waft out of the glass. It's all about intensity, complexity and elegance, delivering mature Marasca cherry, orange zest, licorice and tobacco before closing on a note of smoky flint. Taut but refined tannins provide support while fresh acidity lends perfect balance. Drink 2023–2030.
